content: This is a great simulation logic, but currently, I am wondering if this is really suitable for CoC ? the story is cute, but pretty long and the strict equality checks on floats is a real trap due to precision errors. It looks more like a classic puzzle to me, as it stands now. For a CoC, maybe you can switch everything to INT (just a suggestion) ?

Some things are less than intuitive to me.
1. The additional CPU-instruction is a nice gotcha but does not add anything.
2. The halt instruction is a bit ambiguous. I would expect it to mean halt - full stop - print the output and exit. Halting 4 times seems redundant. 

Alternatively 'H' could mean 'hold', and continue adjusting if another shift occurs. This would be reactive, and thus swap the timing between instruction and shift. As a bonus, this would solve point 1.

It might be too long reverse mode, but I would like to see what percentage of players can do it in under 15 minutes :)

Other than that; good concept, clear statement, fun puzzle!

The author's solution fails on the following case. In Python, 0.1 + 0.2 evaluates to 0.30000000000000004.

0.0 0.3
2
0.1
0.2

Expected:

FFH
0.300 0.300
Success

Result:

FFB
0.300 0.300
Failure
Good catch @kozuechan. I have edited my solution accordingly and modified Test/Validators 6-7 to catch floating point rounding errors.

Hey @RobbertvZ, thanks for the feedback! I included the additional CPU instruction so that the halt instruction becomes intuitive - once the CPU outputs the halt instruction, all movement should cease. I will consider changing the halt instruction to a hold instruction instead and/or only requiring one 'H' instruction if it makes more sense!

Hey @N3I, thanks for the feedback! I don't think the story is that long but I agree that the equality float check can trip some clashers up (including me, oops). I will consider switching to integers as you mentioned, if there is interest in this clash! Right now, I'm leaning more towards scrapping this idea altogether.
